thread.title: Fans flock to see rare 'werewolf cat' at London cat show
thread.title_full: Fans flock to see rare 'werewolf cat' at London cat show

author: Helena Horton
title: Fans flock to see rare 'werewolf cat' at London cat show
text:
Fans flock to see rare 'werewolf cat' at London cat show There are only a couple of werewolf cats in the UK Credit: Eddie Mulholland 
F ans have flocked to see a rare 'werewolf cat' at LondonCats in Surrey. 
The cat show celebrates rare breeds, and this puss is a type coveted by breeders. 
There are only a couple of werewolf cats or Lyoki in the UK, and 9 month Shalnavazz Mehari is a fine example of one. 
The Lyoki is not a recognised designer breed, but instead a type of cat with a genetic mutation which causes it to have an unusual appearance. 
Cat lovers have been able to meet over 200 different felines at the show, which is held over two days, the 7th and 8th of January. 
H owever, the Lyoki is one of the stars of the show. 
The Lyoki cats are domestic shorthairs with hair follicles which lack all the necessary components required to create hair. 
B reeders now purposefully try to continue this mutation, especially in America, where the breed was first created and cultivated. 
The cats are known for being affectionate and playful. 
The werewolf cat isn't the only rare feline at the event; there was also the world premiere of an African Sand Cat cross or the Marguerite, never before seen in public anywhere in the world. The African sand cat cross Credit: Eddie Mulholland 
This sand cat cross was created by breeders Jacky and Tim Bliss crossing a wild sand cat with a British crossbreed. 
T here are 20 Marguerites now, all descended from Trevor the wild cat. 
Mrs Bliss, 63, told the Evening Standard: “This is the first time an African sand cat hybrid has been seen at a public show in the world because this is the first time a successful breeding programme has been completed. The LondonCats show is full of rare and beautiful felines Credit: Eddie Mulholland 
“The two kittens and cat we are bringing to the LondonCats show are second and third-generation hybrids, whereas other sand cat offspring have died.” 
S he said sand cats are “different to those more aggressive wild cats. Sand cats lie flat and hide if they are scared, they don’t attack, and they’re not hyperactive. We are trying to keep those traits in the hybrid domestic cat offspring and they are so sweet-natured.” 
The LondonCats show is known as the 'Crufts for cats' and it's backed by the International Cat Association. Watch | Downing Street Cats: Who are Westminster's most important residents? 01:59
